user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_argument_match:
```c
static bool
check_argument_match (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      char *args)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  struct test_header_param param;

  param.connection = connection;
  param.num_headers = 0;
  ret = MHD_parse_arguments_ (connection,
                              MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND,
                              args,
                              &test_header,
                              &param);
  if (MHD_NO == ret)
  {
    return false;
  }
  /* also check that the number of headers matches */
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != pos->kind)
      continue;
    param.num_headers--;
  }
  if (0 != param.num_headers)
  {
    /* argument count mismatch */
    return false;
  }
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment only iterates a linked list (pos and pos->next) and does not call any functions from <string.h> (memcpy, strcpy, etc.). MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 concerns accesses beyond object bounds caused by string.h functions; none are used here. (A general invalid pointer/NULL-dereference would be a different safety issue, not a Rule 21.17 violation.)
